title: Still a Starr: Prolific Beatles drummer gives a nod to the past with new album, book
text:
By Francois Marchand, Vancouver Sun s new book Photograph unearths some rare images of The Beatles and from Starr’s early days and career. Photograph (Genesis Publications) is at major bookstores and RingoPhotoBook.com. Courtesy of: Photography by Ringo Starr Photograph by: Handout by Ringo Starr/Genesis P , Handout by Ringo Starr/Genesis P 
=== 
UNEDITED: RINGO STARR 
Listen to Francois Marchand’s entire conversation with Ringo Starr on the Unedited podcast below. 
=== 
Subscribe to the podcast via RSS and via iTunes . 
=== 
Ringo Starr and His All Starr Band 
October 9, 8 p.m. at Queen Elizabeth Theatre 
Tickets: $75-$165, plus charges at Ticketmaster 
When Ringo Starr brings his All Starr Band to the Queen Elizabeth Theatre on Oct. 9, it will be on a special day for Beatles fans. 
At first Starr, in a phone conversation from Los Angeles, can’t quite put his finger on what the occasion is. 
“Oh yeah? You’ll have to remind me,” the 75-year-old says. 
When it’s pointed out Oct. 9 is his old Beatles pal John Lennon’s birthday — he would also have been 75 this year — Starr chuckles. 
“Yes, it’s John’s birthday! I spoke to Yoko (Ono) because every 9th of October — I’ve only been twice — they go to Iceland to celebrate John’s birthday. We got an invite this year but, as you know, I’ll be in Vancouver.” 
Starr laughs. 
If you attended the Beatles drummer’s last Vancouver performance with the latest iteration of his All Starr crew — featuring Todd Rundgren, Steve Lukather (Toto), Greg Rolie (Santana), Richard Page (Mr. Mister), Warren Ham and Gregg Bissonette — at the Hard Rock Casino in Coquitlam last summer, you witnessed a love-in moment where the band sang Give Peace A Chance at the end of the show. 
In lieu of a Happy Birthday, this is probably how Starr will mark the occasion of Lennon’s birthday at this year’s concert as well, he admits. 
“I went (to Vancouver) quite a bit in the ’70s with a good friend of mine, Harry Nilsson,” he says. “We would go and hang out in Vancouver because it was quite a rocking town.” 
“What I do in Canada — not quite in Vancouver — is that I rehearse the All Starr Band there,” Starr continues. “We’ve done four different bands in Fallsview (Ontario). I love Canada. That’s just how it is. Like most countries, it’s beautiful. Vancouver is on the West Coast and I live on the West Coast now. I’ve always loved the West Coast because it’s warmer. One year I went to Vancouver and then froze my ass off in Toronto.” 
He laughs. 
Starr indeed has a long history with Vancouver.

When the famed Mushroom Studios building was sold in 2013 (at the time it was home to Hipposonic Studios), I had the opportunity to sift through piles of old photos. 
The one that stood out immediately was a shot of Starr and Nilsson flanked by Brent Shindell (Doucette) and Joel Wade from either the late ’70s or early ’80s, giving their best smiles to the camera. 
Speaking of old photos, Starr recently unearthed a whole treasure trove of his own. Many of the shots are never-before-seen photos taken during his time with The Beatles. 
The shots were collected and recently published in a beautiful volume entitled Photograph, not just echoing the title of Starr’s biggest single as a solo artist but also paying tribute to his love of photography. It’s often forgotten that Starr was the director of photography for The Beatles’ Magical Mystery Tour television special in 1967 (credited under his real name, Richard Starkey). 
“There’s many shots no one has ever seen before,” Starr says of the pictures in his new book. “The story is very simple: I found this huge box of stuff. I was emptying all of the storage places I have around the world and trying to get it all in one spot. That’s when you realize how much stuff you’ve got. 
“Anyway, the joy was that I found this old trunk of photo albums and negatives — hundreds and hundreds of negatives. There were all these shots from the ’60s that were in there, so I thought, ‘What a great thing I’ve found here!’” 
Starr reached out book publisher Genesis, who immediately agreed to cobble together a book. 
Most of the pictures are taken from Starr’s point of view, which gives them a very personal touch. Candid images of Lennon, Paul McCartney and George Harrison abound, with acolytes Brian Epstein and George Martin also shown with levity in mind. 
Starr makes the book more autobiographical by adding childhood photos and other piece of memorabilia like images of the call sheets for The Beatles’ Cavern Club performances signed by Epstein, and the original scribbled lyrics for Don’t Pass Me By, the first song he both wrote and recorded with The Beatles (on the White Album, but written circa 1964). 
Starr was inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame as a solo artist earlier this year, making him the last of the Fab Four to be added outside their work with The Beatles. 
Still, he remains the most prolific, with his 18th solo studio album Postcards From Paradise having been released in March. (Macca has 16 if you discount his albums with Wings.) 
Postcards From Paradise features the assistance of longtime Starr partners Dave Stewart (Eurythmics) and composer/songwriter/arranger Van Dyke Parks (of Brian Wilson/Beach Boys fame), as well as members of the current lineup of the All Starr Band. 
The album’s title song, much like Photograph, is a nod to Starr’s bygone days with The Beatles, Starr weaving a number of classic Beatles song titles into the lyrics. 
“I was trying to work into a song, ‘the lovers are under Mr. Moonlight’ — John Lennon sang that song,” Starr said. “I had several ideas for a song and I started picking Beatles tracks because I Wanna Hold Your Hand and Love Me Do — they all blend into a love song. Anyway I was finding it difficult to put together so I just gave Todd Rundgren the track and all my words. Between Todd and I, we put it together. And I thought it turned out beautiful because Todd is a big-hearted, soulful man. He acts like a big baby but he’s a soulful man.”
